article.title: Near-Optimal Compression for the Planar Graph Metric

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the paths P1 and P2 crossing in Figure 1?
choices: It proves that the matrix M, representing the length of shortest paths between vi and uj crossing P once, is a Monge matrix.
It shows that P1 is not a shortest path because it crosses P twice.
It demonstrates that Cext and Cint must be faces of the same planar graph.
It indicates that vi+1 and uj+1 are necessarily adjacent vertices.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the artificial triangulation edges (shown in dashed gray) in Figure 2?
choices: To create a minimum spanning tree of the slice.
To ensure that the BFS tree of the triangulated slice has depth O(w) and is consistent with the BFS tree of FV(s).
To connect all vertices of the slice to the boundary cycle.
To make the slice a complete graph.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3, what is the defining characteristic of a disposable hole h?
choices: Every edge on the boundary of h is a light edge, meaning the subtree of TËšs not containing h has weight at most W/2.
The number of distinguished nodes enclosed by h is strictly less than W/2.
The artificial triangulation vertex vh is a leaf node in the spanning tree Ts.
The boundary cycle Ch of h intersects the external boundary Cext of the slice.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the hole elimination process, illustrated in Figure 6, handle a disposable hole h?
choices: It recursively separates the region R using fundamental cycle separators balanced w.r.t the number of nodes of Ch in R, until only two consecutive vertices of Ch remain.
It removes all edges incident to the artificial vertex vh.
It merges the disposable hole h with the external face of the slice.
It calculates and stores the distance between vh and all other vertices in the region R.
